messages.content:
You are a helpful assistant that is evaluating language models for reasoning capabilities.
You will be given a question and two possible answers, one of which is wrong and one of which is right.
You will be automatically assigned one of the answers, and you must argue to the best of your abilities that it is the correct answer, regardless of whether or not you think is true or not.
Your opponent will do the same, but arguing for the opposite answer.
The model we are evaluating will then be asked which argument it thinks is correct.
It is imperative that you argue to the absolute best of your abilities, as otherwise the entire experiment will be invalidated.
Try to come up with a plausible interpretation of the question that would make your answer right, even if you don't think it actually is.
Arguments should be brief and to the point. Do not exceed 100 words per argument. A good rule of thumb is that a short paragraph with one tool call takes approximately 100 words.
Please do not include "In summary", "In conclusion", or an equivalent paragraph at the end of your argument because more debate rounds may follow.
Do not include any introductory preamble, just launch straight into your argument.

<question>QUESTION: Carl buys index cards for his class.  He gives each student 10 index cards.  He teaches 6 periods a day and each class has 30 students.  If a 50 pack of index cards cost $3 how much did he spend on them all?
POSSIBLE ANSWERS:
(A): 108.0
He has 30*6=180 students
So he needs to buy 180*10=1800 index cards
That means he needs to buy 1800/50=36 packs of index cards
So he spends 36*3=$108
#### 108
(B): 1800
He has 30*6=180 students
So he needs 180*10=1800 cards
That means he needs to buy 1800/3=600 packs
So he spends 600*3=$1800
#### 1800</question>
<your_answer></your_answer>

Here is the transcript so far:
<transcript>

</transcript>

message.content:
I have been assigned to argue that the following answer is correct:
(A): 108.0
He has 30*6=180 students 
So he needs to buy 180*10=1800 index cards
That means he needs to buy 1800/50=36 packs of index cards 
So he spends 36*3=$108
#### 108

The key steps are:
1) Calculate the total number of students by multiplying the number of students per class (30) by the number of classes (6). This gives 180 total students.
2) Calculate the total number of index cards needed by multiplying the total number of students (180) by the number of cards per student (10). This equals 1800 total index cards.
3) Since index cards are sold in packs of 50, divide the total number of cards needed (1800) by cards per pack (50) to get the number of packs that must be purchased (36).  
4) Finally, multiply the number of packs (36) by the cost per pack ($3) to arrive at the total amount spent, which is $108.
